In order to install Ubuntu, you need to parition your drive. Don't use Windows-based partitioning tools to create partitions on which you're going to install Ubuntu.
Boot into Ubuntu from the Live CD and click on Install. Use the partitioning tool in the installer to do set up your partitions. :)

okay, here's a very basic summary of the types of file systems. ntfs is windows-only. ext3 and ext4 are for linux. fat16/fat32 partitions can be easily accessed by both linux and windows. And you need a swap partition as well
You can choose from the installer whether you want to it use your entire drive, or just install alongside Windows.
